there is potential race condition since ifChangeInformNextHop is called in the context of port notification thread. ifChangeInformNexthop further called validnexthopinNextHopGroup/invalidnexthopinNextHopGroup, to iterate over m_syncdNextHopGroups and modify the next hop group member without lock. 

orchagent is essential single thread application, we need to schedule the port notification event to the main loop.

@lguohan validnexthopinNextHopGroup/invalidnexthopinNextHopGroup doesn't add/delete group members at the orchagent level. It does so only in syncd and there is a mutex on the db. I don't see the racing condition you are referring to.
there are now two threads accessing m_syncdNextHopGroups, one is from main thread, now you add another one from port notification. data needs to be protected.
@lguohan membership of m_syncdNextHopGroups is not modified.
does not matter, the main thread could modify, you can still get into trouble.
did we ever tested the case when all nexthop are down and a route points to a nexthop group with zero nexthop group member?
@lguohan Yes 8 months ago during UT. Shuotian also tested this case and verified.
hmm, sai changed from 1.0 to 1.2. Do we have any further test when sai 1.2 is released?

@lguohan Did Broadcom SAI implementation change the behavior of the remove_next_hop_group_member API and all of a sudden it deletes the nexthop groups that have no members? I don't see something like that in the code and if that was the case, then the subsequent call to remove the group on a delete after all the members are deleted, would have resulted in a crash and would be visible even without my code changes. A lot more things would be broken by now.

How did you hit this problem?  For warm start, we have tried to load and process them in order.

If it is because of some race condition in regular operation,  say,  route interface deleted but arp message comes late to orchagent,  it  might cause a persistent entry left there with this change.

It can be easily repro in warm start. I believe there is no race condition. The starting process is:
1. BufferOrch: blocked by gPortsOrch->getPort
2. PortsOrch: blocked by gBufferOrch->isPortReady
3. IntfsOrch: blocked by gPortsOrch->isInitDone
4. NeighOrch: Since router interface creation is delayed in previous step, the task in m_toSync is erased (This is the bug)
5. ...
6. BufferOrch: finish tasks
7. PortsOrch: finish tasks
8. IntfsOrch: finish tasks
9. NeighOrch: no tasks at all
10. RouteOrch: blocked by m_neighOrch->hasNextHop

So the warm start will leave many routes unprocessed.

I don't have idea of your proposed situation, and never met it. In my investigation, this is really a bug.

> If it is because of some race condition in regular operation, say, route interface deleted but arp message comes late to orchagent, it might cause a persistent entry left there with this change.

Under this assumption with my PR, a new neighbor will try to created on a non router interface port, it will be left in m_toSync. However, netlink will soon update with a deleting message, and Consumer::addToSync() will make overwrite the previous one with this new DEL one.

> It looks all the problems are caused by the inter-dependency between portorch and bufforch.

This is not the root cause. The root cause is risk between neighbor messages and router interface messages. In future, the router interface may be configurable, so the risk may happen more frequently.

I agree with you that if arp delete message always comes after arp new message,   then no need to worry about persistent neigh event in orchagent.

The issue with warm reboot PortInitDone is that it is available immediately in the DB read and gPortsOrch->isInitDone() is set to true.   while actually the port level processing is pending on finish of bufferorch. 

While most other orches only check gPortsOrch->isInitDone() and assume everything about port has been ready, this brings too much dynamics and potential issues into warm start, and even cold boot.

First the credit for implementing warm reboot should be given to you. My implementation is just inspired by your solution. I admitted your solution is working, also mine. There are some design principle we should consider for comparison.

1. The Consumer could restore its previous state, not because it has a table in CONFIG_DB, but because it has a SubscriberStateTable.
2. The SubscriberStateTable by design has 2 data source and 2 phases. First from initial table content, and later field value update. The first data source and phase fit the design of Orch::addExistingData() and Consumer::refillToSync() perfectly, so it's a nature extension. ref [https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/blob/master/common/subscriberstatetable.cpp](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/blob/master/common/subscriberstatetable.cpp)
3. The second phase of SubscriberStateTable are for config updating. By design, this should not be handled by warm reboot, but processed normally after warm reboot
4. SubscriberStateTable/ConsumerTable/ConsumerStateTable are on the same abstract level. The state restoring should be implemented on the same level. The best implementation should be if-else branching or virtual functions.

I should point not-that-good design choices I found:

1. At the abstract level above Consumer, user should not care too much about the underlying redis database index and table name
2. Introduce new collaboration between processes, such as freezing redis, or send a special warm reboot event. I don't mean they are totally forbidden, but for warm reboot, they are not necessary. The design of every components could handle the use case well, with some reasonable extension like this PR.


Let me know if you find more design or implementation issues in this PR.

Design discussion:
1. The orchagent/neighorch.cpp has warm starting feature now. Its responsibility is propagate all the neigh entries in ApplDb to downstream syncd
2. The design principle of neighsyncd is just sync netlink messages to downstream orchagent, there is no state concept in neighsyncd
3. APP_NEIGH_TABLE is the implementation detail of orchagent, and neighsyncd should not read it or assume anything there.

I proposed another design choice, similiar to INIT_VIEW and APPLY_VIEW between orchagent and syncd. The warm start process of neighsyncd:
1. orchagent/neighorch.cpp warm starts, not processing data in ProducerStateTable
2. neighsyncd sends a STALE event to orchagent through ProducerStateTable, so orchagent marks existing neigh entries stale
3. neighsyncd collects all the neigh from netlink, and propagate to orchagent, and then propagate to syncd
4. neighsyncd sends a APPLY event to orchagent, so orchagent del all left stale neigh entries, and then propagte to syncd
   
This choice has some advantages:
1. The warm start features of neighsyncd and orchagent are independent, ie. we could restart only neighsyncd anytime
2. There is no timer logic
 #Pending

The design was proposed a while back but I am happy to discucss more if needed here. 

I disagree with a few points in your design discussion:
- It is fine that orchagent/neighorch.cpp can propagate the neighbor entries in AppDB to syncd, but that has nothing to do with who should do the reconciliation. 
- neighsyncd is the owner/producer of the APP_NEIGH_TABLE, it will definitely need understand the table and should be the one to do reconciliation of the table.

In principle, neighsyncd should not be part of swss at all and should be in another system.

The design you proposed is just making both systems to be coupled together rather than to decouple them.  It makes the design complicated without any benefit:
 - With the design of the current implementation, you can restart neighsyncd at any time. 
 - Timer was the signal to tell system to do the reconciliation,  it plays the same role on either design choice. e,g, we use it to send APPLY_VIEW signal in your choice. 
    In case, there is discussion to eliminate the timer all together, that is not something to do with this design choice but the choice of using timer or not. 

Also, in your design choice, rather than providing benefit, it confuses responsibility of the producer or consumer of tables.  The consumer (orchagent) should not manipulate the table like neighbor_table by any means.

Sorry, I am not aware of previous proposed design. Forgive me if you are pushed to discuss again.

> neighsyncd is the owner/producer of the APP_NEIGH_TABLE, it will definitely need understand the table and should be the one to do reconciliation of the table.

Neither statements is not correct. There are 2 redis storage related to APP_NEIGH_TABLE, one is the plain table

```
127.0.0.1:6379> keys *NEI*
 1) "NEIGH_TABLE:PortChannel0004:10.0.0.63"
 2) "NEIGH_TABLE:PortChannel0003:10.0.0.61"
 3) "NEIGH_TABLE:eth0:10.3.146.75"
 4) "NEIGH_TABLE:eth0:10.3.146.1"
```

the other one is a virtual queue between ProducerStateTable and ConsumerStateTable. The 2nd is implemented by Redis SET and HASH(s).

```
127.0.0.1:6379> SMEMBERS "NEIGH_TABLE_KEY_SET"
1) "eth0:10.3.146.184"
2) "lo:0.0.0.0"
3) "eth0:10.3.146.3"
4) "eth0:10.3.146.1"
5) "eth0:10.3.146.187"
127.0.0.1:6379> keys _NEIGH_TABLE:*
1) "_NEIGH_TABLE:eth0:10.3.146.187"
2) "_NEIGH_TABLE:eth0:10.3.146.1"
3) "_NEIGH_TABLE:eth0:10.3.146.3"
4) "_NEIGH_TABLE:eth0:10.3.146.184"
5) "_NEIGH_TABLE:lo:0.0.0.0"
```

The neighsyncd is using ProducerStateTable to enqueu data. The orchagent/neighorch.cpp is using ConsumerStateTable to dequeu data and manipulate the plain table. So the owner of APP_NEIGH_TABLE is orchagent. The orchagent has the freedom to dequeue anytime it finds bandwidth, so the manipulate the plain table may be delayed.

When you manipulate the plain table in neighsyncd, there may be entries left in the queue. There will be data inconsitent issue. So I said

I was aware of the internal "virtual queue" of the redisDB. As matter of fact, that was more a implementation details of RedisDB, and it does the SPOP and HSET etc to populate the plain table in the lua script.  That does not change the ownership of the APP TABLE at all. The data in the APP TABLE should be managed by the application like neighsyncd.
I see a trend to put more and more logic into orchagent, probably because we are more familiar with that part of the code, but this breaks the design principle, and confuses the source of true.

Let me add my thoughts on this...

From an SWSS standpoint, who's the producer of neighbor/routing state in the system? If we agree that the information is produced by neighsyncd and fpmsyncd, and that this information is injected in a centralized data-store, why would you want a third-party to be the one carrying out the reconciliation process?

What if orchagent is restarted along fpmsyncd? How would orchagent find out about zebra<->fpmsyncd re-connection events?

Looks like we are unnecessarily putting all eggs in the same basket, while at the same time we are stretching orchagent semantics. Also, as i previously mentioned, running the reconciliation logic down in orchagent trenches prevent us from being able to provide a clean solution for kernel-routing-reconciliation -- coz we don't want orchagent to talk back to kernel, that would be ugly.

The possible solution is to check the temporary table used by producerState,  if it is empty then all buffered data has been consumed by orchagent.  

Applications(neighsyncd, fpmsyncd,..) make sure the specific temporary table  is empty before reading existing data from regular table for reconciliation task.  

Implementation wise, it should be very simple to add a isEmpty() method to ProducerStateTable class.

But for pre-shutdown state check, pipeline flush is needed to avoid data loss.
@jipanyang Yes, we we can do pre-shutdown flush and empty check for producerState table after warm-started.
@jipanyang Yes, that was that I meant and wrote. :-)

No matter where the comparison and reconciliation is done for arp and route, fpmsyncd/neigsyncd or orchagent,  we could make them work.
The concerns with doing that in orchagent are:
<1> Orchagent has various dependency processing, once the data is in orchagent it builds up connection with other related objects,
doing comparison and reconciliation for arp and route in orchagent would be more complicated than doing the same task in fpmsyncd or neigsyncd.

<2> Currently the interface between orchagent and application is simple and straightforward, producerstate/consumerstate. Once the phase concept is introduced between them,
the interaction will be become rather complex, race condition may be introduced, I expect seeing a series bugs with it, which could be avoided if we just let neighsyncd and fpmsyncd do their job alone.   We have got a lot headache with the simple port configDone/InitDone signals.

But I agree that there are some common logic with the comparison and reconciliation for different objects, we should try to extract out the common functions for reuse (among route, arp, fdb and etc.)

For the case of NEW and Delete arp messages,  probably the write operation could be done immediately.  It seems there is no reason to delay them to the very end?   They don't affect the marking of stale entries.

@jipanyang Regarding the question about write DELETE/NEW entries to AppDB directly, I think it should be fine to wait a little amount of time instead of pushing right away.  The idea was to expand this logic to more tables, but some application could flap entries in the beginning of restart, e,g have delete and add for the entry,  by waiting to things to be settled, we could eliminate any potential traffic interruption.

As discussed,  common library functions for "compare and push" or "mark and sweep" should be extracted. The common library functions may be used for arp, route, and other types of objects which have the need to identify delta data.      

Well defined common library functions should not block possible local optimization like the incremental push of arp entries, but we may have a working library first then see how to improve from there.

The existing implementation was targeting swss docker warm restart assuming stateDB and host netdev not touched.

As to system warm reboot,  for going up path, we need to make sure syncd/libsai/SDK have finished their tasks ( one of tasks is to recreate host interfaces), probably syncd should set a flag in stateDB (maybe reuse WARM_RESTART_TABLE, state=reconciled).  Then swss starts it tasks.

Since no real order control between portsyncd/portmgrd and orchagent,  we should not re-apply the default config in port config file which may cause port state flapping and other unwanted consequence.  While portmgrd has all up to date data for all config it had applied before shutdown, it is ok for it to replay the data. 

As to portState in StateDB,  it is an indication that netdev has been created.  During warm reboot, libsai/SDK/syncd should have guaranteed that state,  the easy way is to save and restore it during reboot.  Note, swss needs the state reconciled signal from syncd in stateDB to proceed.

Just my 2cents about port state restore during system warm reboot.  Of course there are other alternatives to the problem.

For port state in stateDB, either `save and restore` if we want to rely on the flag from lower layer,  or portsyncd check the existence of each netdev and set the state again. can you explain the nature of the race condition more clearly?

At the execution that the detection script detects a storm, the script publishes the storm event to pfcwdorch. The immediate next execution of the detection script is expected to get pfc_wd_status ~= 'operational' to exit the detection logic and return. This expects the pfcwdorch to finish processing the storm occurrence event and get all actions taken within one polling interval. In a bad timing, however, pfcwdorch may not have processed the storm event to set the queue PFC_WD_STATUS in COUNTERS_DB properly by the time the immediate next execution of the detection script is called. 

By resetting SAI_PORT_STAT_PFC_?_RX_PKTS_last and _RX_PAUSE_DURATION_last at the storm detection execution, the immediate next execution of the detection logic will skip the main detection logic. This allows the pfcwdorch to get the storm event processing done within a timeline of two polling intervals, not the previous one polling interval. By increasing the time window, the double detection case is expected to be largely reduced if not fully mitigated in some pfcwdorch extremely non-repsonsive cases.

@jipanyang thanks for your comments.

There are good reasons for this added complexity, which may also provide extra flexibility to other applications in the future:

- We need to deal with multi-field values (e.g. 1.1.1.1/30 nh: 10.1.1.1, 10.2.2.2, if: eth1, eth2)
- We need to deal with different orders in multi-field values (e.g. 1.1.1.1/30 nh: 10.2.2.2, 10.1.1.1, if: eth2, eth1)
- And we need to deal with partial updates coming from the north-app (e.g. first we get "1.1.1.1/30 nh: 10.1.1.1, if: eth1", and then we get the complete prefix: "1.1.1.1/30 nh: 10.1.1.1, 10.2.2.2, if: eth1, eth2")

@rodnymolina @jipanyang @lguohan 

**Design Comments**

I always viewed sonic's *syncd parts (fpmsyncd, neighoborsyncd etc.) as thin stateless layers that provide intermediate yet very simple functionality and means of communication, between major sonic parts. Their functionality only goes as far as knowing the format of the data they are manipulating but not necessarily the meaning of it. This view is also reinforced if one looks at the current code and understands the functionality.

With this and other PRs I see that we are diverging from that paradigm. At the same time I haven't seen compelling technical justification to do so or some existing technical debt that needs to be addressed which pushes us in that direction.

We seem to be converting *syncd parts into a stateful layer with additional needless complexity, code duplication and exploding memory requirements just to satisfy the needs of warm restart.

A divergence from the current design will allow us to get the functionality we want without the drawbacks exhibited here. I will point out the issues I see in the current design and then I will outline solutions to counter them in order of preference.

**Current Design**

- Keeping state per path is needless and results in convoluted comparison code. Routes always get implicitly updated rather than incremental per path updates. Eliminating this will probably result in a much simpler design with likely half the code changes.
- Path sharing is not happening. This means every prefix will point to its own set of paths duplicating information on a per prefix basis. For a 4-way ecmp prefix, the memory increase will be roughly 8x. 12K prefixes in fpmsyncd will feel like 100K when doing warm restart in terms of memory consumption. This is too much to ignore.
- We have now turned fpmsyncd into a stateful part of sonic. Adding state always increases interaction and complexity by definition.

**Alternative Designs**

1. Keep fpmsyncd stateless
This personally is my preferred approach and aligns best with the existing sonic design. During warm restart, fpmsyncd clears the appdb queue, starts a timer and informs orchagent (through appdb). Upon timer expiration it tells orchagent again. The orchagent will be the one responsible for marking prefixes as stale and cleaning up when the timer expires. Currently orchagent has code that suppresses routes where nothing has changed. So it has all the comparison logic in place to achieve that already. Quagga and FRR don't keep quiet upon restarts and churn the prefixes as they are learned. The appdb queue can suppress that if we want to or we can fix the issue in frr with minimum effort and quagga with moderate effort.

Pros:
- fpmsyncd remains stateless and with no memory increase.
- orchagent is the one doing the route reconciliation (which is where it should be IMO).
- With new path attributes, only the format knowledge part of fpmsyncd changes so that it understands what it's reading and how to push that info to the db. So fpmsyncd's warm restart part doesn't need to be retested.

Cons:
- Slight increase in complexity from the signalling of the start/stop timer through the appdb.

2. Stateful fpmsyncd and with path sharing.
Read routes from appdb and partially use the code from routeorch to reconstruct prefixes, ecmp groups etc. and share ecmp groups across prefixes. Read from fpm socket and construct a different set of prefixes but reuse the ecmp groups. On timer expiration, go through the prefixes and compare if they point to the same ecmp group and send only the delta down. Alternatively we can make this even simpler and just download the whole table paying attention only to the stale prefixes which need to be deleted. As I said above, routeorch already has code that suppresses prefixes where nothing has changed so sai/asic won't be notified needlessly.

Pros:
- Can minimize to only the delta on what is sent to the db.
- Partially share code with routeorch for reconstructing view.
- Need to change 2 different components and retest both when new path attributes are introduced (orchagent and fpmsyncd) and retest warm restart.
- Path sharing with this solution.

Cons:
- fpmsyncd is now stateful and a bit more complex with increased memory needs during a restart.

3. Stateful fpmsyncd and no path sharing.
Similar to the above but without any path sharing.

Pros:
- Can minimize to only the delta on what is sent to the db.

Cons:
- fpmsyncd is now stateful and more complex.
- Exploding memory consumption requirements.
- No code sharing with orchagent for reconstructing view.
- Need to change 2 different components and retest both when new path attributes are introduced (orchagent and fpmsyncd) and retest warm restart.

So the current reconciliation implementation has the assumption that application will always have fix number of FieldValueTuple.  Ex. for route BGP always provide two fields "nexthop" and "ifname",   for neighbor, they are "family" and "neigh".   

If there is any violation of this assumption,  the reconciliation won't work.   It is also related to the ProducerStateTable issue: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/issues/236  

I think it is ok for now.  Further update could be done when more flexible cases emerge.  Could you put a little more information about this  in the code comment field?
